body: @vinothchandar can you share the patch PR? is it related to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HIVE-11266 ?

Hmmm I usually do the following workflow. 

```
git fetch origin
git fetch hudi # replace with whatever is your remote pointing to apache/incubator-hudi
git checkout master
git rebase hudi/master
git checkout your-branch
git rebase master # resolve conflicts if any, run tests again
git push origin your-branch --force # this updates the PR
```

@ambition119 does that help

> Hmmm I usually do the following workflow.
> 
> ```
> git fetch origin
> git fetch hudi # replace with whatever is your remote pointing to apache/incubator-hudi
> git checkout master
> git rebase hudi/master
> git checkout your-branch
> git rebase master # resolve conflicts if any, run tests again
> git push origin your-branch --force # this updates the PR
> ```
> @ambition119 does that help

For almost the same operation, the commands I use are as follows:
```shell
$ git remote add apache https://github.com/apache/incubator-hudi.git
$ git fetch apache
$ git rebase apache/master
$ git push     // or git push origin master
$ git checkout -b hudi_63
```
then hudi_63 branch dev and pull request merge.  thank you!

> awesome.. can you please squash the commits again? :)

I use these command :
```shell
$ git remote add apache https://github.com/apache/incubator-hudi.git
$ git fetch apache
$ git rebase apache/master
$ git push     // or git push origin master
$ git checkout -b hudi_63
```
 not 
```shell
git fetch hudi # replace with whatever is your remote pointing to apache/incubator-hudi
git checkout master
git rebase hudi/master
git checkout your-branch
git rebase master # resolve conflicts if any, run tests again
git push origin your-branch --force # this updates the PR
```

So, if I squash the commits. How should I operate it? Can you explain for me? Thank you!

@ambition119 squashing is different.. I think those are for rebasing (original error you reported).. 

https://gist.github.com/jbub/5766366 does something like this work? 
`git rebase -i HEAD^2` to squash last two commits. Then you do `p` for first one and `s` for rest.. It will ask you to reenter a combined commit message. 
Once you save that, a new commit will be added replacing the 2 you had. 

Catch now is you need to force push this branch to update PR after you have squashed it. i.e `git push origin hudi_63 --force`
closing due to inactivity

> @ambition119 squashing is different.. I think those are for rebasing (original error you reported)..
> 
> https://gist.github.com/jbub/5766366 does something like this work?
> `git rebase -i HEAD^2` to squash last two commits. Then you do `p` for first one and `s` for rest.. It will ask you to reenter a combined commit message.
> Once you save that, a new commit will be added replacing the 2 you had.
> 
> Catch now is you need to force push this branch to update PR after you have squashed it. i.e `git push origin hudi_63 --force`

@Achuth17 : This was  done on purpose. There are lot of different hadoop/hive environments out there. With Hudi having to interoperate across different query engines, it was practical to choose a set of hadoop/hive releases for which we can certify different hoodie tools/jars.  As part of this certification, we found that blindly picking all jars results in package conflicts with this ones present in the installations.

Hudi just supports Spark at the moment. Flink support is being discussed on the mailing list. 

Coming to what you are trying to do here, seems like you need the HoodieDeltaStreamer to be deployed as a continuously running streaming job.  We def want to get to that point eventually https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HUDI-70 please engage here if interested. 

For starters, I think it will be a lot easier to either 

1. Add a while(true) loop in the HoodieDeltaStreamer with a `--long-running` mode to keep running what it does in a loop? (its a simple patch to the tool)
2. Try the StructuredStreaming sink (contributed by Vungle folks, seems to be working for them)
lets continue on the mailing list..  !

As per my understanding only `HoodieAvroPayload` is now used by `SpillableMap`. I added the serialization method to interface so, other payload classes can also extend this.

Since i am new to this project, i may be missing other parts. Guidance on this PR will be highly helpful. Thanks in advance :)

Can you please share you understanding of `super.close()` in this context ? So, super is basically the current instance of FileSystem being extended by the current instance of HoodieWrapperFileSystem. The HoodieWrapperFileSystem also holds an instance of the underlying file system as a member variable. What wil super.close() behavior be here once it is invoked ?
@ambition119 Could you please rebase and resubmit this PR ?
Couple of minor comments, rest looks good, can approve once addressed

@lyogev Thanks for starting a contribution to the project! The bundles are supposed to package all the necessary dependencies. Can you give a short summary of the issue you faced which was solve by your above mentioned approach ?

@n3nash hi, so you can check out this branch here:
https://github.com/YotpoLtd/metorikku/pull/164

Or more specifically the docker compose I used for my E2E spark test:
https://github.com/YotpoLtd/metorikku/blob/hudi/e2e/hudi/docker-compose.yml

The way we're running our project is via spark-submit.
I tried adding your original hoodie-spark-bundle by using the ```--packages``` parameter and the ```--jars``` parameter.

But I had trouble with both.
In some cases I was getting:
```
java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: hoodie-file:... does not have a open stream. Cannot get the bytes written on the stream
```

Once I got passed that, when it reached the hive-sync stage I got:
```
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: com.uber.hoodie.org.apache.hadoop_hive.conf.HiveConf
```

Upon looking at the bundle I saw that hive wasn't actually bundled at all (since it inherited ```provided``` scoping from the parent).
I changed the scoping to ```compile```  but then I got:
```
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.optimizer.ppr.PartitionExpressionForMetastore cannot be cast to com.uber.hoodie.org.apache.hadoop_hive.metastore.PartitionExpressionProxy
```

So in the end I had to both bundle hive into the jar and also make sure it's not shaded, since something internal in hive was not handling the shading well.

There is a big chance I'm missing something here, but my end goal is to provide an easy access to **Hudi with Metorikku**  by only adding a single JAR (2 is also OK :) ) to the spark-submit.

Makes sense?

Well `super.close()` is pretty obvious. Its the FIleSystem class's close(), which does some clean up of the cache etc. @bvaradar pointed out that it might be good to clean it up for the `HoodieWrapperFileSystem` instance.. 

I still think closing the wrapped file system, is not a good idea, since its cached globally across jvm.

`ReflectionUtils.loadPayload` was still constructing the new instance of `HoodieRecordPayload` object based on the constructor, so i thought it would be good to have a method enforced on the interface rather than on constructor.

If the issue is not valid, l am happy to close this PR, will pick up some other task from JIRA board :)

See https://github.com/apache/beam/search?q=ProcessContext&unscoped_q=ProcessContext

@SemanticBeeng this is orthogonal to connection management I believe.. This ticket was around figuring out how to deploy hudi in a long running mode.. Some aspects like givining up containers on dynamic allocation etc could still be useful. let me post this into HUDI-70
Once we approach beam, we can consider ProcessContext. for now, I think SparkStreamingContext or equivalent would do something similar I beleieve

Sorry figured it out.
Created a class:
```
class EmptyHoodieRecordPayload extends HoodieRecordPayload[EmptyHoodieRecordPayload] {
  def this(record: GenericRecord, orderingVal: Comparable[_]) {
    this()
  }

  override def preCombine(t: EmptyHoodieRecordPayload): EmptyHoodieRecordPayload = t
  override def combineAndGetUpdateValue(indexedRecord: IndexedRecord, schema: Schema): Optional[IndexedRecord] = Optional.empty()
  override def getInsertValue(schema: Schema): Optional[IndexedRecord] = Optional.empty()
}
```

And then set dataframe writer to:
```
    writer.option("hoodie.datasource.write.payload.class", "....EmptyHoodieRecordPayload")
```

@n3nash HUDI-72 tracks this

@arunlakshman Thanks for the explanation, I see what you are trying to say. The `Remove payload class dependency in SpillableMap` is a slightly different issue than the one you are trying to propose.
 
That intention of removing payload there is to support spillable map for any type T instead of a HoodieRecordPayload (which was the implementation before). I think I'll close HUDI-61 since it's not valid anymore. 

What you are suggesting is valid, we require a way to be able to instantiate the payload without enforcing some sort of constructor although this changes the HoodieRecordPayload interface making it sort of non-backwards compatible if we assume we want to deprecate the constructor way going forward. I've opened this issue : https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HUDI-93. 

Although, I would suggest you to punt on this change since this requires some discussions and suggest you to take a look at https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/HUDI/issues/HUDI-92?filter=allopenissues is that interests you. If not, you can always see which other task interest you!

@lyogev : Thanks a lot for reporting the issue. We needed to selectively include and shade a subset of hive dependencies for hoodie to work across hive versions with Spark (http://hudi.incubator.apache.org/quickstart.html#version-compatibility). Having said that, there is an issue causing hive dependencies to not get included in hoodie-spark bundle. 

Can you try this patch and see if this resolves the problem.

https://gist.github.com/bvaradar/289134ac30f5103696918713e0d9bb1a

As you expect, the plan is to use only one hudi bundle. You should include only hoodie-spark bundle if you are using spark-shell/spark-submit. If you are planning to use delta-streamer for ingesting data, you should only use hoodie-utilities bundle. This jar also has hive/spark dependencies included.

Balaji.V

Created a new module `hoodie-bench`

Current Limitations & workarounds
- Cannot specify which specific partitions one wants to generate updates for, the suite will generate updates across any N partitions. Although, if you wanted to test updates for specific partition only, you can simply generate a dataset with 1 partition and then generate updates for that.
- No concrete implementation around compaction, scheduling compaction, rollback but basic building blocks have been implemented.

Hi.. please post on the mailing lists for faster responses.. https://hudi.apache.org/community.html 

We don't currently publish snapshot/night releases.. We just build master locally and work off local repository..  Would that be useful for you?

Hi.. please leave us a note on the dev mailing list for faster response. 
https://hudi.apache.org/community.html 

> Did I missing some hudi config in writing pipeline?

For Spark SQL, you need to push the path filter as documented here. https://hudi.apache.org/querying_data.html#spark-ro-view 
Getting duplicates typically means, this  is missing..  

> Why the commit is still inflight but parquet file can be generated?

So, the sequence of events is . We write parquet files and then upon successful writing of all attempted parquet files, we actually make the commit as completed. (i.e not inflight anymore). So this is normal. This is done to prevent queries from reading partially written parquet files.. 

>  In hudi, did the commit finish and then spark .save finish so there is no asynchronous problem?

.save() internally calls hoodieWriteClient.commit(). 

> Is there any reader side config issue with hive output format ? since it's org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.io.parquet.MapredParquetOutputFormat

OutputFormat is not really used anywhere by Hudi. So no.
